title: R43222
content: More U.S. merchandise trade is carried by oceangoing vessels than by airplanes, trucks, freight trains, and pipelines combined. Harbor maintenance plays a critical role in facilitating U.S. foreign trade and reducing trade costs between different regions. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers is responsible for maintaining federal navigation channels, and the Water Resources Development Act is the main legislative tool for altering harbor maintenance policy. The Water Resources Development Act (WRDA) is the main legislative tool for altering harbor maintenance policy, with decisions on harbor maintenance having a significant impact on the U.S. economy. The cost of harbor maintenance is supported by a harbor maintenance tax (HMT) on imported and domestic waterborne cargo and cruise passengers, with the tax rate at 0.125% of the value of cargo shipped or cruise tickets sold. The tax is generally assessed at coastal and Great Lakes ports, with almost all revenue generated by imported waterborne cargo. The harbor maintenance tax rate is 0.125% of the value of cargo or cruise tickets, generating revenue mainly from imported waterborne cargo. The tax funds the harbor maintenance trust fund (HMTF) for dredging channels, maintaining jetties, and operating locks. HMTF surplus reduces the federal budget deficit, with over half of the annual revenue spent on harbor maintenance. The Harbor Maintenance Tax funds the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund (HMTF) for dredging channels and maintaining jetties. The trust fund balance was $8.5 billion in July 2013, with annual revenue of $2.05 billion expected in FY2014. Bills in Congress aim to increase spending on harbor maintenance, requiring HMT revenues to be used for this purpose. Bills in the 113th Congress aim to double annual spending on harbor maintenance by using Harbor Maintenance Tax revenues for this purpose. H.R. 3080 proposes increasing HMTF expenditures each year, with 80% of the prior year's HMT collected funds to be spent on harbor maintenance by FY2020. This increased spending may impact funding for other Corps activities like harbor construction or flood control. Congress could offset this by allocating more funds to the energy and water development. Congress established the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund (HMTF) in 1986 to pay for eligible operations and maintenance costs of commercial navigation in harbors and inland harbors. Increasing HMTF expenditures may impact funding for other Corps activities, such as harbor construction or flood control, requiring Congress to allocate more funds to the energy and water development appropriation. The Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund (HMTF) was established by Congress in 1986 to cover maintenance costs for commercial navigation in harbors and inland harbors. The definitions of "harbors" and "inland harbors" were outlined by Congress, with a key distinction being that inland harbors must currently handle cargo. These definitions have remained unchanged since 1986, and the Corps did not conduct a rulemaking to implement the provisions. The Corps interprets the term "commercial navigation" to mean any project authorized by Congress with commercial navigation as an authorized purpose. Most harbor projects are authorized as "single-purpose" commercial navigation projects, with all O&M costs payable from the HMTF. If a project is authorized as a "multi-purpose" project, only expenditures for commercial navigation and joint-use costs are covered by the HMTF. In high-use ports, 90% of maritime commerce is handled, with two-thirds of HMTF spending going to these ports in FY2013. Moderate-use ports, accounting for 9% of commerce, received 19% of HMTF spending. Low-use ports make up 7% of commerce. In FY2013, "moderate use" ports handling 1-10 million tons of cargo received 19% of HMTF spending, with 7% of "low use" ports also having federally funded O&M projects planned. This allocation of funds sparked debate over how HMTF funds should be distributed between high, moderate, and low-use ports. H.R. 3080 aims to prevent funds from being allocated solely based on tonnage, while S. 601 appears to prioritize funding for large commercial cargo ports.
